solution.text:
Total surface area of all the cubes \(= 5 \times 6 \times 1.6^2 = 76.8 cm^2\)
Area of each face =\(1.6^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 76.8 - 25.6 = 51.2 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 14 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(51.2 \times 14\)
= Rs. 716.8

content.text: Five cubes of edge 1.6 cm each are placed side by side and stuck together as shown. The cost of painting is Rs 14 per \(cm^2\). What is the cost of painting the outer surface of the entire object?

hint.text: Count the number of faces that are outward facing

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\pi \times \frac{30}2 \times 20 + 2 \pi \times \frac{10}2 \times 20 + 2\pi({\frac{30}2}^2 - {\frac{10}2}^2)\)
= 3771.43\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 3771.43 \times 0.2\)
= Rs. 754.29

content.text: A cylindrical pipe has an outer diameter of 30 cm and an inner diameter of 10 cm. Its length is 20 cm. It needs to be painted on its outer and inner surfaces, as well as the rims. The cost of painting the pipe is Rs. 0.2 per \(cm^2\). What is the total cost of painting the pipe?

hint.text: Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims

Cost of painting the box = Rs. 2.8 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the box = \(1496 \times 2.8\)
= Rs. 4188.8

content.text: Latika needs to paint a rectangular box from the outside. The cost of painting the box is Rs. 2.8 per \(cm^2.\) If the dimensions of the box are \(22 cm \times 22 cm \times 6 cm\), what is the total cost of painting the box?

solution.text:

Area of base = Area of Triangle = \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times side^2 = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 43^2\)
=\(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 1849 cm^2\)
Therefore, volume of water added = Area of base \(\times\) Rise in water Level
=119953.88 \(cm^3\)
Since 1L =\(1000cm^3\)
Volume of water added = 119.95 L

content.text: The water tank in Rekha’s house has a base in the shape of an equilateral triangle with each side measuring 43 cm. It is filled with water till a height of 3 metres. She pours some more water into the tank and the new level is 4.5 metres. What volume of water did she pour into the tank? Use \(\sqrt{3} = 1.73\)

hint.text: Area of an equilateral triangle = \(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times side^2\)

solution.text:

\(= \frac 12 \times 28 \times (22 +\) River Side Length\()\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{1148}{14} - 22\)
\(= 60 m\)

content.text: Hussain bought a plot of agricultural land which is in the shape of a trapezium (see below). The area of the land is \(1148 m^2\), the side parallel to the road is 22 metres and the width of the field is 28 metres. How long is the side parallel to the river?

hint.text: The area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times Height \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)

Therefore, r = 2.39 cm
Volume of a cylinder \(= \pi r^2h = 322.16 cm^3\)

content.text: Rajiv likes to make 3D shapes from paper. Yesterday, he started with a rectangular piece of paper of length 18 cm and breadth 15 cm. He then rolled the paper into a cylinder so that the cylinder is now 18 cm long. What is the volume of the air inside the cylinder so formed?

solution.text:
Curved Surface area of the roller \(= 2 \pi rh = 2\pi \times \frac {6}2 \times 10 = 188.57 cm^2\)
Area covered per rotation \(= 188.57 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area painted in 50 rolls \(= 188.57 \times 50 = 9428.57 cm^2\)

content.text: Last Monday, Ram painted a rectangular wall with a cylindrical paint roller. The length of the roller is 10 cm and its diameter is 6 cm. While painting, the roller rolled over 50 times completely. What surface area did Ram paint?

hint.text: How much area does the roller cover in one rotation?

solution.text:
Volume of pipe=Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder
\(= \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= \pi (19)^2 \times 34 - \pi(17)^2 \times 34\)
= 7693.71\( cm^3\)
\(Mass = Volume \times Density\)
\(\Rightarrow Mass = 7693.71 cm^3 \times \frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\)
= 66165.94 g

\(=2483 m^2\)

You are the engineer in charge of the project. Can you use the information given below to calculate the area of the garden? a = 80 m, b = 39 m, c = 49 m, d = 13 m

Rise of water level = h = 11 cm
Therefore, volume of rain water harvested \(= 101828.57 \times 11 = 1120114.29 cm^3\)
1 L \(= 1000cm^3\)

content.text: You have set up a rain-water harvesting system at your home. A cylindrical container with a radius of 18 dm collects rain-water from your roof. It rained last Monday and some water was collected, raising the height of water in the container by 11 cm. What volume of rain water was collected?

hint.text: Volume of a cylinder = \(πr^2h\). Also note that 1dm = 10cm

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 122 \times 37 + \frac 12 \times 49\times(122 + 92)\)
\(= 9757 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 7 km/hr = 7000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 9757 \times 7000 = 68299000 m^3/hr\)
= 68299 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 68299\)
= 11474232 megalitres

content.text: The Vashishti river flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. You measure the dimensions of the river and find that a = 122 m, b = 92 m, c = 37 m and d= 86 m. The river flows at a constant rate of 7 km / hr. What volume of water (in megalitres) flows into the sea over the course of a week? Note that 1 megalitre = 1000000 litres

solution.text:
The volume of the tank \(= 34 cm \times 30 cm \times 30 cm \)= 30600
Rate of flow into the tank = 8L/minute = 8000\(cm^3\)/minute
Therefore, time taken to fill tank completely \(= \frac {30600}{8000} \)= 3.825 minutes

content.text: Water is pouring into a cuboidal tank of length 34 cm, breadth 30 cm and height 30 cm at the rate of 8L/minute. How many minutes will it take to fill the tank completely?

hint.text: Volume of a cuboidal container = lbh

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 5553.43 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (11)^2 \times 31 - \pi (11-x)^2 \times 31\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{31\pi}=11^2 - (11-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (11-x)^2 = 121 - \frac{V}{31\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 11 - 8\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

content.text: The volume of a metallic cylinder pipe is 5553.43 cubic centimetres. Its length is 31 cm and its external radius is 11 cm. Find its thickness

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 176 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{176}{\pi} = 56 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 176 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 176 + 56\)
= 73.6 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(176 cm^2\). You then cut a straight slice from the cake (as shown below) such that the volume of the slice is exactly \(\frac {1}{10}\) of the volume of the cake. What surface area of your slice has no icing?

hint.text: Think about your slice as a separate object. What faces do not have icing?

solution.text:
Volume of the brick wall \(= 15 m \times 3 m \times 0.5 m = 22.5 m^3\)
Volume of one brick \(= 20 cm \times 10 cm \times 5 cm = 1000 cm^3\)
\(1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3\)
Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 22.5 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 22500\)

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 6782.29 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {15}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {15}{2} - 6)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {15}2)^2-\pi (\frac {15}2 - m)^2}\)
= 39.96 cm

Volume of the small cube \(= 6^3 cm^3\).
Therefore, number of cubes that can be cut \(= \frac {12^3}{6^3} = 8\) cubes

Therefore, area of tin required for 8 boxes \(= 256 \times 8\)
\(= 2048 cm^2\)

content.text: The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 936 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(936 m^2\)
Therefore, \(936 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{936}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{9}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 3 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid?

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 11200 m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 20 \times 14 = 280 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 400000

content.text: The area of your school library floor is \(11200 m^2\). You are asked to use tiles in the shape of a parallelogram with a base of 20 cm and a height of 14 cm to cover the floor. How many such tiles will you need to purchase? You can break the tiles in any way to cover the entire floor.

hint.text: Start by finding the area of each tile.

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 7392\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{7392}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{7392}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {7392\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 28 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 14 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 34496 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 7392 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder

\(= 462000\) L

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Trapezium (2) + Area of Triangle (3) + Area of Triangle (4) + Area of Triangle (5)
\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 38 \times 39 + \frac 12 \times 86.5 \times 58 + \frac 12 \times 47.5 \times 28.5 + \frac 12 \times 38 \times 47.5 + \frac 12 \times 77 \times 38\)
\(=6652.875 cm^2\)

\(= \frac 12 (a+c)(h) \times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (21 + 28)(14) \times 2\)
\(= 686 mm^2\)

hint.text:
Remember the following formulas:
Volume of a Cube: \(side^3\)
Surface Area of the Cube:\( 6 \times side^2\)
Volume of a Cuboid: \(length \times breadth \times height\)
Surface Area of the Cube: \(2 \times (lb + bh + lh)\)

Surface area of a cylinder:\(2\pi r(r+h)\)

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 15^2 \times 49 = 34650 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 34650 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 27 \times 16 \times h = 34650 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {34650}{27 \times 16} = 80.21\)
The new cuboid is 80.21 cm tall

content.text: A metal cylinder of height 49 cm and radius 15 cm is melted and reshaped into a cuboid of length 27 cm and breadth 16 cm. No metal was wasted during this process. How tall is the new cuboid?

\(\Rightarrow\) Length of side = \((\frac {600}{6})^{\frac 12} = 10 cm\)

V \(= \pi r^2h\)

Therefore, the volume will quadruple

A cylinder has a radius r, a height h and a volume V
